11:22 am
BE11:22am

Here's page one.

BE11:22am

We upgrade Micro Focus to Buy from Neutral and raise our 12-month price target to 1,700p (from 1,300p). Following a period of significant M&A execution issues which led to turbulent sales growth in FY18, we believe that the dust is starting to settle at Micro Focus. An in-line FY18 trading update suggests that revenue declines are moderating and sell-side estimates have likely bottomed. In our view, cost synergies from the integration of HPE Software, and ongoing and future capital returns, should come to the fore with the stock trading at a near term trough multiple of 7.5x 2019E PF EPS and revenue declines not deteriorating further.

chopper bear flybee ? please
Excel Developer Yesterday afternoon, GBPUSD popped to £1.30 on the rumour of a deal then sold off. haha.
Viking1 TonaldDrump, do not have the note
BE11:24am

And spinning down to the sale of Suse, which looks a doubly terrible deal on the back of IBM's Red Hat purchase but what do I know ......

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Active capital returns strategy remains at the forefront: The current Micro Focus management led by Executive Chairman Kevin Loosemore has employed an active capital returns policy since 2010 with the company’s stated long-term objective to deliver total shareholder returns of 15%-20% pa. We believe the significant share price underperformance YTD in 2018 will focus attention on the cash returns strategy (share buybacks, special dividends) as the executive management’s long-term incentivisation is linked to TSR. MCRO has already announced a share buyback of $400 mn from the current balance sheet before the completion of the sale of its growth asset SUSE to private equity, which the company expects to close in 1Q19. While we do not take a view on completion of this deal, we note that the agreed sale price for SUSE represents c.30% of MCRO’s current market cap.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

The key economic questions are what any political declaration on future relations will say. While not binding, the document will almost certainly be treated as the guideline for further negotiations by the EU27. The document and its level of detail, alongside the backstop solution, will have some weight in determining how long the transition may last and what comes thereafter. Before that, however, the political questions are whether May can get the deal through cabinet (yes, apparently) and Parliament (difficult, but not impossible, in our view) and whether there will be any hiccups in the EU27 ratification, and what happens if the deal doesn't get through (renegotiation, Article 50 extension, Conservative Party leadership contest, new elections or second referendum). Uncertainty could easily increase further in the coming weeks. It is worth considering also however, that if the deal successfully passes Parliament before Christmas, economic confidence, BoE rate hike expectations, sterling and gilt yields could rebound earlier than many expect.

rw42 Dunno, what i've read reported about the withdrawal agreement so far suggests it's not hard enough for leavers, not soft enough for remainers, and demonstrably worse for both sides than our current deal. Don't think it would be the worst thing in the world to ask why the hell we're still going through with it!
chopper bear the wonderful people at betfair are offering 1.44 on no ref before 2020
alewis2005 I'll take your 10-1. Lots of agitators behind the scenes pushing to change the conversation.
Deep Breath everyone... @Flaneur - not sure about break-up, but revisiting of Barnett formula/West Lothian question likely
MassimoJ @chad_john i'm not sure a 2nd ref will lead to blood on the streets. i think you're overestimating how important this is to people
chad_john alewis2005 - and those voices will only get louder, but as per above what will happen is intense unrest, possibly dangerous.
BE11:30am

And Kit at SocGen, if you want the FX view.

Excel Developer briefed to BBC correspondent: “If the officers won’t stop this then the poor bloody infantry will have to” - ERG bod on PMs Brexit deal
BE11:30am

 A 2pm Cabinet meeting will be held after which we will find out whether she succeeded in passing that first hurdle. If she doesn’t, pressure to resign will mount. If she does, the show moves on to trying to garner support for her deal in the House of Commons. The opening salvos from the DUP, hard Brexiteers in the Conservative ranks, and the leadership of the Labour party, suggest this will be very hard indeed. Therefore, even if white smoke comes out of the top of the Downing Street chimney this afternoon and agreement is announced, any further GBP rally is likely to be short-lived as we return to a familiar state of uncertainty.
 I put a chart of EUR/USD and GBP/USD in my blog on Monday, showing how they have been dragging each other down. I have recreated thee same chart gong back to 2009 and added a second, which shows EUR/GBP and EUR/USD. EUR/GBP and EUR/USD used to move closely together back in the days before the referendum. Just glancing at the chart suggests that if Brexit went away, EUR/GBP ‘ought’ to trade around 0.70-0.75, i.e. 15% or so stronger than current levels. That isn’t going to happen of course, but it is a way of thinking about how much damage Brexit has already done to the pound. More realistically, if the deal as described in the press were to pass into law, both GBP and EUR would benefit, and sterling could well trade above USD 1.35 as EUR/USD got a lift too. I fear however, that a return of uncertainty will see sterling end the day weaker and that is likely, in turn, to refocus FX market attention on a 12 bp widening in the BTP/B und spread this morning, and a 0.2% fall in German Q3 GDP. Eurozone Q3 GDP data are due later. Another test of EUR/USD 1.12 seems likely this week.

Shinshin @lewis the only people agitating for a second ref are the people with absolutely no ability to introduce a second ref. Not going to happen.
Flaneur *to clarify - no in/out 2nd ref - wouldnt rule out a Hard exit/Easy exit vote though. Tories cant risk election.

BE11:32am

[T]he arithmetic suggests that a deal will not receive parliamentary ascent at first attempt.

BE11:33am

Once you have accounted for Sinn Fein that don’t take theirs seats, the Speaker and his 3 deputies, you need 320 votes to reach a majority.
May has around 150 ‘payroll votes’ (paid government jobs + ministerial assistants) and 85 conservative loyalists taking the
total number the PM can count on to 235 – leaving another 85 votes that she needs.
There are around 5 Labour MPs who believe in Brexit and are likely to support the government, even if some may not like
the deal enough to support it. There are up to 20 Labour MPs, representing pro-Brexit districts that may defy the Labour
whip and accept repercussions that may bring. That would bring the number May needs from here to 60 votes – or 260 votes
she can reliably count on.
The DUP (10 votes) has come out already in a statement and refused to back the current deal. There are up to 10 Europhiles
that are also unlikely to support the deal. There are 51 Tory Brexiteers that have joined “Stand up for Brexit”, a campaign
specifically criticizing the deal, broadly in its current form. There are anywhere between 60 and 80 Tory MPs that are part
of the ERG – many will overlap with the 'Stand up for Brexit' contingent. One important question is whether this contingent
will vote against a deal or simply abstain.
Against the government's deal will be around 75 pro-European Labour MPs, around 155 Labour Loyalists and 52 MPs from the remaining smaller parties or a total of 282 MPs.

Excel Developer ERG Peter Bone has a question at PMQs
11:33 am
BE11:33am

While this first vote looks doomed, making predictions from here on a complex political process becomes more difficult.
We think the most likely scenario from here is that with the clock ticking in the background ever louder, at some point it
will dawn on the various factions inside parliament that the marge de manoeuvre MPs enjoy is actually quite limited.
Leadership challenge, general election and a second, 'people's vote' should eventually fade as possibilities (the latter because
it requires an extension of Article 50 which we think will only be granted if the purpose of it is to hold a referendum with a
simple choice between leaving the EU with the proposed deal or staying in the EU – as opposed to the three-way
referendum that even Remainers in the UK recognize needs to be politically an option).
MPs are likely to realize that the only realistic choice they have is between leaving with no-deal or leaving with the
proposed deal the government has spent the best part of two years negotiating.

BE11:33am

If this is true, we think it reasonable to assume, no matter how inferior the deal is considered, that faced with the prospect of
crashing out a few weeks later without a deal, a sufficient number of MPs will overcome their concerns and support the
government. Importantly, though, we believe they will only do so once it has become clear that no other path is open to
them. This may take time and can only be achieved after the first vote in parliament, possibly after the second. This will
take us in all likelihood into mid-January.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

[A]dverse effects on the UK economy would far outweigh any benefits from positive translation effects from foreign earnings and a weaker currency.
The effects of a no-deal scenario are indeed vast and wholesale – to model the impacts is extremely difficult and will among
others depend on contingency measures and regulatory ‘patches’ that both sides agree.
However, it is worth pointing out that should we really get to that point and the UK has ultimately rejected a deal that took two years to negotiate, often at a frustratingly slow and erratic pace, after it has decided to leave the EU in the first place and after it will in all likelihood have rejected paying for commitments the EU considers the UK to be liable for, we think it is fair to assume very little help and goodwill from the EU to ease the pain.
